STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 16, 2024
Jill Schreuder
CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN - GR
40 JEFFERSON AVE,
GRAND RAPIDS, MI, 49503-4304
Re: License #: CB410245705
SI #: 2024SIC0001518
Dear Jill Schreuder:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2024SIC0001518
Special Investigation Intake Date: June 17, 2024
License #: CB410245705
Licensee Group Organization: Catholic Charities West Michigan
Licensee Designee: JILL CHRISTINE SCHREUDER
Chief Administrator: Jill Schreuder
Agency Name: CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN -
GR
Agency Address: 40 JEFFERSON AVE
GRAND RAPIDS, MI 49503-4304
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 01/19/2025

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Placement
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404
Section • (4) An agency shall consider all the following factors in
Description selecting an appropriate placement for a child:
• (a) Proximity to the child's parents, family, or
community.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is considering placing youth in a home in Kalamazoo
which would make it impossible for the parent to have regular
contact.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant was interviewed by phone on 6/25/2024 at which
time Complainant reiterated the concerns in the initial complaint.
Complainant also stated Complainant believed Foster Care
Worker has been making every effort to keep Youth A in a local
placement, but Complainant is concerned if local placement can’t
be found, Parent A won’t be able to visit Youth A as much as she
would like.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/25/2024 and reported the Adult Foster Care (AFC) home in
which Youth A is currently living put in a 30-day notice for him to
be moved by the end of May due to his extensive needs. Foster
Care Supervisor stated there are weekly meeting with the team
involved in Youth A’s case, including staff from his current
placement, foster care agency staff, West Michigan Partnership
for Children (WMPC,) and his behavioral health team to discuss
needed supports for his current placement as well as efforts to
locate new placement. Foster Care Supervisor stated placement
search has been focused within Kent County to ensure Parent A is
2

able to visit, but there have been no residential facilities willing to
accept the youth due to the severity of his needs and no AFC
homes willing due to his not turning 18 until October and/or the
severity of his needs. Foster Care Supervisor reported Youth A
was interviewed for placement in Kalamazoo at a residential
facility as a “last resort,” but that facility did not accept Youth A.
She stated efforts continue to be made to locate a placement
within Kent County.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/25/2024 and reported the AFC home where Youth A is currently
placed put in a 30-day notice to have him moved, which has
expired. She stated the home is willing to allow Youth A to stay
until a new placement is secured. She reported he was
interviewed by a facility for placement in Kalamazoo, but that was
a last-ditch effort, and that facility did not accept him. She stated
there have been some local AFC homes that will consider
accepting Youth A after he turns 18 in October, but there are no
definite plans yet.
Behavior Analyst was interviewed by phone on 6/25/2024. She
reported Youth A’s current placement gave a 30-day notice to
have Youth A moved and Foster Care Worker considered a
placement in Kalamazoo. She stated that placement did not
accept Youth A, but Behavior Analyst is concerned that Foster
Care Worker is considering placing Youth A too far away from
Parent A for Parent A to continue visiting. Behavior Analyst is also
concerned about Youth A potentially being placed out of county
because he has had the same behavioral health team for two
years and moving him out of county would result in his loss of that
team. Behavior Analyst reported she believed Foster Care Worker
is making every effort possible to keep Youth A in a local
placement.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• 10/2/2023 Court Order documenting Youth A’s permanency goal
was changed to Another Planned Permanent Living Arrangement
(APPLA) and visitation between Youth A and Parent A is at
agency discretion.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as Complainant, Behavioral
Analyst, Foster Care Worker, and Foster Care Supervisor all
report Foster Care Worker is making every effort to maintain a
local placement for Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
3

Rule Code Placement
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404
Section • (4) An agency shall consider all the following factors in
Description selecting an appropriate placement for a child:
• (b) The physical, emotional, and educational needs
of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The youth's needs are not being met in his current placement.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant was interviewed by phone on 6/25/2024 and
reiterated the concerns in the initial complaint.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/25/2024 and reported Youth A regressed significantly when he
moved to the Adult Foster Care (AFC) home in which he is
currently placed, which she believed is attributed to the fact he
was used to being the only person in his previous placement and
now he is placed with several other people. She stated the staff at
his current placement have not been able to be as attentive as the
previous placement where it was essentially one to one staffing.
Foster Care Supervisor stated the current placement has recently
implemented one to one staffing which has resulted in Youth A’s
progress beginning to improve. Foster Care Supervisor stated
there are weekly meetings with the team involved in Youth A’s
case, including staff from his current placement, foster care
agency staff, WMPC, and his behavioral health team to discuss
support needed by his current placement as well as to assess the
services he is receiving.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/25/2024 and reported the worker assigned to Youth A’s case at
the time of his replacement is no longer with the agency, but
Foster Care Worker has heard that Youth A’s progress has
declined since being in his previous placement. She stated she
believed some of that was due to Youth A’s tablet being broken so
he was not able to communicate. She also stated the placement is
now being paid for one-to-one staffing, which Foster Care Worker
believes will be beneficial to Youth A.
Behavior Analyst was interviewed by phone on 6/25/2024. She
reported Youth A’s needs are not being met in his current
4

placement. She stated Youth A was the only youth in his previous
placement and now he is placed with multiple adults, one with
whom he shares a room. Behavior Analyst stated Foster Care
Worker is making efforts to assist the placement in meeting Youth
A’s needs such as securing funding for one-to-one staffing.
Behavior Analyst is concerned the placement will not be able to
consistently provide the one-to-one staffing, despite having the
funding to do so.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• Case Service Plan completed 5/30/2024 documenting Youth A’s
placement was appropriate as Youth A received one-to-one
staffing, ABA services 8 hours a day, appropriate 24/7 care, and
his medical and dental appointments are up to date.
• Case record documenting his medical and dental appointments
are completed timely, and he is receiving appropriate education.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance with considering the youth’s
physical, emotional, and educational needs as Complainant,
Behavior Analyst, Foster Care Supervisor, and Foster Care
Worker report the agency staff have secured one to one staffing
for Youth A’s current placement. Additionally, weekly meetings are
held to provide support to the placement and to assess the care
Youth A is receiving.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Placement
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404
Section • (4) An agency shall consider all the following factors in
Description selecting an appropriate placement for a child:
• (d) Expressed preferences of the child, and the
child's parent or parents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency is not consulting with the parent while searching for
an appropriate placement for the youth.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant was interviewed by phone on 6/25/2024 and
reiterated the concerns in the initial complaint. Complainant also
stated Complainant does not know first-hand what information is
being communicated to Parent A.
5

Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/25/2024 and reported Foster Care Worker makes attempts via
text messaging and emails, utilizing, a language translation
application, to update Parent A. She stated the agency has also
recently hired a Spanish speaking staff member who has assisted
Foster Care Worker in communicating with Parent A. Foster Care
Supervisor reported Parent A has a good relationship with Youth
A’s behavioral health team and she is much more responsive to
them than Foster Care Worker, despite attempts made by Foster
Care Worker to engage Parent A.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/25/2024 and reported she texts Parent A regularly with updates
regarding Youth A and placement attempts. She stated she
utilized Google translate to send those messages as Parent A
only speaks Spanish. She stated Parent A will text back at times,
but she isn’t always responsive. Foster Care Worker stated Parent
A has been present for the Family Team Meeting held by Foster
Care Worker following Youth A’s placement issuing a 30-day-
notice as well ,and an interpreter was present to assist with
providing updates regarding the case.
Behavior Analyst was interviewed by phone on 6/25/2024. She
reported she doesn’t know what Foster Care Worker is
communicating to Parent A, but Parent A told her she isn't
involved in the decision to place Youth A in his current placement.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• 10/2/2023 Court Order documenting Youth A’s permanency goal
was changed to Another Planned Permanent Living Arrangement
(APPLA.)
• 5/13/2023 Family Team Meeting paperwork documenting Parent
A was present for the meeting, as well as a language interpreter,
during which Youth A’s placement and future placement options
were discussed.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as, despite Youth A’s goal
having been changed to APPLA, agency staff involved Parent A in
a Family Team Meeting to discuss efforts to locate a new
placement for Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

Rule Code Change of placement
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12405
Section • (3) The agency shall document all the following in the
Description child's record before a change of placement occurs:
• (f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The parent went to visit her child at his placement and discovered
he was no longer living there. The agency did not notify the parent
of the replacement.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant was interviewed by phone on 6/25/2024 and
reiterated the concerns in the initial complaint, including Youth A’s
foster care worker at the time Youth A was moved told
Complainant she has left a voicemail message for Parent A about
the move. Complainant was concerned as Parent A only speaks
Spanish and that worker only spoke English.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/25/2024 and reported the worker and supervisor assigned to the
case at the time Youth A was moved are no longer with the
agency and there is a lack of documentation within the record, but
she would look through the paper files and documents to see if
she can find anything to upload into the case record.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/25/2024 and reported she was not assigned to the case at the
time Youth A was replaced and the worker who was is no longer
employed by the agency. She stated she is unaware if/how Parent
A was notified of the move.
Behavior Analyst was interviewed by phone on 6/25/2024. She
reported she messaged Parent A when Youth A was moved
because Behavioral Analyst was with Youth A during the move.
Parent A did not respond to that message. Behavior Analyst sent
another text to Parent A at 7:00PM after which Parent A
responded to Behavioral Analyst that she was on her way to the
previous placement for a visit as she wasn’t told Youth A was
moving that day. Behavior Analyst reported she brought it up to
7

the foster care worker the following day, who said it was “well
documented” that Parent A was told about the move.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• Youth A’s case record in which no documentation of Parent A
being notified of Youth A’s change in placement was documented.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as documentation that
Parent A was notified of Youth A’s move was not located within
Youth A’s case record.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section • (3) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
Description parents and children except where parental rights have
been terminated or when there is a court determination that
visits are detrimental to the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency has not been assisting in facilitating in person visits
with the youth and parent for approximately 12 weeks.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant was interviewed by phone on 6/25/2024 and
reiterated the concerns in the initial complaint.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/25/2024 and reported she was informed at the time she was
assigned to the case in March of 2024 that Parent A needed
transportation assistance to visit Youth A. Foster Care Supervisor
stated she does not know what Parent A was told about bus
access, but it is a far walk to the nearest bus stop. Foster Care
Supervisor reported there was confusion regarding the
transportation being utilized by Parent A which likely caused a
delay in the previous worker obtaining financial assistance. Foster
Care Supervisor stated Foster Care Worker was able to confirm
Parent A is utilizing a taxi service for her visits and was able to get
paperwork from Parent A regarding the costs. Foster Care
Supervisor stated a reimbursement check has already been
issued to Parent A and Foster Care Worker is in the process of
setting up an account with the taxi service so the agency can pay
for Parent A’s transportation directly.
8

Foster Care Worker was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/25/2024 and reported Parent A’s son used to drive her to
visitation with Youth A; however, he is no longer allowed to be at
Youth A’s placement due to a no contact order, so Parent A is
now taking a taxi to the visits. Foster Care Worker stated she was
told during a meeting by Youth A’s behavioral health staff that
Parent A was utilizing Uber, so Foster Care Worker was
attempting to locate information about paying for Uber. When
Foster Care Worker got a receipt from Parent A for a visit, it was
from a taxi service. Once Foster Care Worker got that information,
she submitted a request for payment. She stated a check for 39
trips has been issued to Parent A. Foster Care Worker stated she
is working with the taxi company to set up an account so the
agency can pay them directly for Parent A’s transportation to
visits.
Behavior Analyst was interviewed by phone on 6/25/2024. She
reported Youth A’s previous foster care worker told Parent A that
Youth A’s placement was on the bus route. Youth A’s Court
Appointed Special Advocate subsequently researched the bus
route and discovered the placement was not on the bus route. The
foster care worker then told Parent A the agency would pay for an
Uber gift card for mom to use for visits with Youth A, but Parent A
has been paying herself. Behavior Analyst stated she is not aware
what efforts have been made by Foster Care Worker to secure
funding for Parent A’s transportation.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• 10/2/2023 Court Order documenting Youth A’s permanency goal
was changed to Another Planned Permanent Living Arrangement
(APPLA) and visitation between Youth A and Parent A is at
agency discretion.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as they have secured funding
to assist Parent A in visiting Youth A, despite Youth A’s goal being
APPLA and visitation ordered at the discretion of the agency.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Development of service plans
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418
Section • (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
Description and the foster parents in the development of service plans
to enable the parent or parents and foster parents to
understand the plan for the child and the parents' and the
foster parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying out
9

the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and review the
parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or
parents and foster parent that the information in the parent-
agency treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency has not involved the parent in decision making
regarding the youth's treatment and service planning.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant was interviewed by phone on 6/25/2024 and
reiterated the concerns in the initial complaint.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/25/2024 and reported Youth A’s current goal is APPLA and
Parent A is no longer participating in services. She stated she
believes Parent A signed a non-participation agreement prior to
the goal change and would look for that agreement. After her
interview, Foster Care Supervisor sent an email stating she
misspoke about the non-participation agreement and Parent A
had not signed such an agreement; however, Youth A’s goal was
changed to APPLA during a court hearing in October of 2023.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via video conferencing on
6/25/2024 and reported she was told Parent A signed a non-
participation agreement. She stated Youth A’s goal was changed
to APPLA in October of last year. Foster Care Worker stated
Parent A was present for the Family Team Meeting held by Foster
Care Worker since her assignment to the case as well and that an
interpreter was present to assist with providing updates regarding
the case. She stated Parent A also attended the most recent court
hearing before which Foster Care Worker met with her along with
an interpreter to go over all the case updates. Foster Care Worker
stated she is scheduling another meeting with Parent A to make
sure she understands Youth A’s goal.
Behavior Analyst was interviewed by phone on 6/25/2024. She
reported she doesn’t know what conversations are held between
Foster Care Worker and Parent A, but Parent A has told Behavior
Analyst she has not been involved in decisions regarding Youth A
and has not been informed of court hearings. Behavior Analyst
stated Parent A was present at a hearing Behavior Analyst
attended in 2022. She stated she knows Parent A attended the
most recent court hearing . Behavior Analyst stated she wasn’t
10

aware if Parent A signed a non-participation agreement, but she
does know the court ordered Youth A’s goal to be changed to
APPLA.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• 10/2/2023 Court Order documenting reasonable reunification
efforts were made, Youth A’s parents did not make progress
toward alleviating or mitigating the conditions that led to Youth A’s
placement in foster care, and the permanency goal is changed to
Another Planned Living Arrangement (APPLA.) Parent A was not
present; however, Parent A’s attorney was present for the hearing.
• 5/13/2023 Family Team Meeting paperwork documenting Parent
A was present for the meeting, as well as a language interpreter,
during which Youth A’s services were discussed.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as Youth A’s permanency goal
is APPLA which does not require agency staff to engage Parent A
in a treatment plan.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
______________________________________July 15, 2024
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 15, 2024
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
11
